channel.title: Nature Materials
channel.description: Nature Materials is a multidisciplinary journal aimed at bringing together cutting-edge research across the entire spectrum of materials science and technology. Nature Materials covers all applied and fundamental aspects of the synthesis/processing, structure/composition, properties and performance of materials. Nature Materials provides a forum for the development of a common identity among materials scientists while encouraging researchers to cross established subdisciplinary lines. To achieve this, Nature Materials takes an interdisciplinary, integrated and balanced approach to all areas of materials research while fostering the exchange of ideas between scientists involved in different communities.

item.title: Breaking the rule of reciprocity in soft composite solids
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02435-z

Borrowing an idea from granular physics, researchers design and engineer soft composite materials with non-reciprocal static and dynamical mechanical behaviours, which could power the next generation of soft robots.
item.dc:title: Breaking the rule of reciprocity in soft composite solids
item.dc:creator: Jie Zhang

item.title: Shining a light on interfacial conductivity
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02427-z

Ultraviolet illumination dramatically increases electrical conductivity at the interface between two oxide compounds.
item.dc:title: Shining a light on interfacial conductivity
item.dc:creator: Berit H. Goodge

item.title: Ultrafast time-resolved observation of non-thermal current-induced switching in an antiferromagnetic Weyl semimetal
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 04 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02402-8

This study reveals spatiotemporally resolved current-induced switching in Mn3Sn thin films, identifying both thermal and non-thermal mechanisms depending on the amplitude of the current.
item.dc:title: Ultrafast time-resolved observation of non-thermal current-induced switching in an antiferromagnetic Weyl semimetal
item.dc:creator: Kazuma Ogawa
Hanshen Tsai
Naotaka Yoshikawa
Takumi Matsuo
Yutaro Tsushima
Mihiro Asakura
Hanyi Peng
Takuya Matsuda
Tomoya Higo
Satoru Nakatsuji
Ryo Shimano

item.title: Super-expansive thermo-reversible interstitial solid solution of nanocrystal superlattices with mesogens
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 28 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02388-3

Combining liquid crystals and nanocrystals functionalized with promesogenic ligands yields an interstitial colloidal solid solution exhibiting high thermal expansivity and reversible superlattice phase transitions driven by mesogen diffusion.
item.dc:title: Super-expansive thermo-reversible interstitial solid solution of nanocrystal superlattices with mesogens
item.dc:creator: Shengsong Yang
Dai-Bei Yang
Yifan Ning
Yugang Zhang
James M. Kikkawa
Jeffery G. Saven
Christopher B. Murray

item.title: Two birds with one stone
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 27 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02426-0

A technique combining laser fragmentation in liquids with the reduction of multiple metal salt precursors is developed to synthesize alloy nanoparticles, simultaneously achieving ultrasmall size and high compositional complexity for efficient and stable electrocatalysis.
item.dc:title: Two birds with one stone
item.dc:creator: Christoph Rehbock
Stephan Barcikowski

item.title: One additive for all
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 27 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02429-x

Adding an ammonium propionic acid stabilizes the phases of both the middle and top perovskite layers, which further enables efficient and stable perovskite/perovskite/silicon tandem solar cells.
item.dc:title: One additive for all
item.dc:creator: Dewei Zhao
Liang Li
